original_text: Production of charmonium states J/ψ and ψ′ in nucleus–nucleus collisions has been studied at CERN SPS over the previous 15 years by the NA38 and NA50 Collaborations. This experimental program was mainly motivated by the suggestion [1] to use the J/ψ as a probe of the state of matter created at the early stage of the collision. The original picture [1] (see also [2] for a modern review) assumes that charmonia are created exclusively at the initial stage of the reaction in primary nucleon–nucleon collisions. During the subsequent evolution of the system, the number of hidden charm mesons is reduced because of: (a) absorption of pre-resonance charmonium states by nuclear nucleons (normal nuclear suppression), (b) interactions of charmonia with secondary hadrons (comovers), (c) dissociation of cc̄ bound states in deconfined medium (anomalous suppression). It was found [3] that J/ψ suppression with respect to Drell–Yan muon pairs measured in proton–nucleus and nucleus–nucleus collisions with light projectiles can be explained by the so-called normal (due to sweeping nucleons) nuclear suppression alone. In contrast, the NA50 experiment with a heavy projectile and target (Pb+Pb) revealed essentially stronger J/ψ suppression for central collisions [4–7]. This anomalous J/ψ suppression was attributed to formation of quark–gluon plasma (QGP) [7], but a comover scenario cannot be excluded [8].
original_translation: La producción de los estados de charmonio J/ψ y ψ′ en colisiones núcleo-núcleo ha sido estudiada en el CERN SPS durante los últimos 15 años por las Colaboraciones NA38 y NA50. Este programa experimental fue principalmente motivado por la sugerencia [1] de utilizar el J/ψ como una sonda del estado de la materia creada en la etapa temprana de la colisión. La imagen original [1] (ver también [2] para una revisión moderna) asume que los charmonios son creados exclusivamente en la etapa inicial de la reacción en colisiones primarias de nucleón-nucleón. Durante la evolución subsiguiente del sistema, el número de mesones de encanto oculto se reduce debido a: (a) absorción de estados de charmonio pre-resonantes por nucleones nucleares (supresión nuclear normal), (b) interacciones de charmonios con hadrones secundarios (comovers), (c) disociación de estados ligados cc̄ en un medio deconfinado (supresión anómala). Se encontró [3] que la supresión de J/ψ con respecto a los pares de muones Drell-Yan medidos en colisiones de protones-núcleo y núcleo-núcleo con proyectiles ligeros puede ser explicada solo por la llamada supresión nuclear normal (debido a la barrida de nucleones). En contraste, el experimento NA50 con un proyectil y blanco pesados (Pb+Pb) reveló una supresión de J/ψ esencialmente más fuerte para colisiones centrales [4–7]. Esta supresión anómala de J/ψ fue atribuida a la formación de plasma de quarks y gluones (QGP) [7], pero un escenario de comovers no puede ser excluido [8].

original_annotated_sentences:
Production of
charmonium states
J/ψ and ψ′ in nucleus–nucleus collisions has been studied at CERN SPS over the previous 15 years by the NA38 and NA50 Collaborations.
This experimental program was mainly motivated by the suggestion [1] to use the J/ψ as a probe of the state of matter created at the early stage of the collision.
The original picture [1] (see also [2] for a modern review) assumes that charmonia are created exclusively at the initial stage of the reaction in primary nucleon–nucleon collisions.

During the subsequent evolution of the system, the number of hidden charm mesons is reduced because of: (a) absorption of pre-resonance
charmonium states
by nuclear nucleons (normal nuclear suppression), (b) interactions of charmonia with secondary hadrons (comovers), (c) dissociation of cc̄ bound states in deconfined medium (anomalous suppression).

It was found [3] that J/ψ suppression with respect to Drell–Yan muon pairs measured in proton–nucleus and nucleus–nucleus collisions with light projectiles can be explained by the so-called normal (due to sweeping nucleons) nuclear suppression alone.
In contrast, the NA50 experiment with a heavy projectile and target (Pb+Pb) revealed essentially stronger J/ψ suppression for central collisions [4–7].
This anomalous J/ψ suppression was attributed to formation of quark–gluon plasma (QGP) [7], but a comover scenario cannot be excluded [8].

Este programa experimental fue principalmente motivado por la sugerencia [1] de utilizar el J/ψ como una sonda del estado de la materia creada en la etapa temprana de la colisión. La imagen original [1] (ver también [2] para una revisión moderna) asume que los charmonios son creados exclusivamente en la etapa inicial de la reacción en colisiones primarias de nucleón-nucleón. Durante la evolución subsiguiente del sistema, el número de mesones de encanto oculto se reduce debido a: (a) absorción de estados de charmonio pre-resonantes por nucleones nucleares (supresión nuclear normal), (b) interacciones de charmonios con
hadrones
secundarios (comovers), (c) disociación de estados ligados cc̄ en un medio deconfinado (supresión anómala). Se encontró [3] que la supresión de J/ψ con respecto a los pares de muones Drell-Yan medidos en colisiones de protones-núcleo y núcleo-núcleo con proyectiles ligeros puede ser explicada solo por la llamada supresión nuclear normal (debido a la barrida de nucleones). En contraste, el experimento NA50 con un proyectil y blanco pesados (Pb+Pb) reveló una supresión de J/ψ esencialmente más fuerte para colisiones centrales [4–7]. Esta supresión anómala de J/ψ fue atribuida a la formación de plasma de quarks y gluones (QGP) [7], pero un escenario de comovers no puede ser excluido [8].

original_annotated_sentences: Production of charmonium states J/ψ and ψ′ in nucleus–nucleus collisions has been studied at CERN SPS over the previous 15 years by the NA38 and NA50 Collaborations.
This experimental program was mainly motivated by the suggestion [1] to use the J/ψ as a probe of the state of matter created at the early stage of the collision.
The original picture [1] (see also [2] for a modern review) assumes that charmonia are created exclusively at the initial stage of the reaction in primary nucleon–nucleon collisions.

During the subsequent evolution of the system, the number of hidden charm mesons is reduced because of: (a) absorption of pre-resonance charmonium states by nuclear nucleons (normal nuclear suppression), (b) interactions of charmonia with secondary hadrons (comovers), (c) dissociation of cc̄ bound states in deconfined medium (anomalous suppression).

It was found [3] that J/ψ suppression with respect to Drell–Yan muon pairs measured in proton–nucleus and nucleus–nucleus collisions with light projectiles can be explained by the so-called normal (due to sweeping nucleons) nuclear suppression alone.

In contrast, the NA50 experiment with a
heavy projectile and target
(Pb+Pb) revealed essentially stronger J/ψ suppression for central collisions [4–7].
This anomalous J/ψ suppression was attributed to formation of quark–gluon plasma (QGP) [7], but a comover scenario cannot be excluded [8].

Se encontró [3] que la supresión de J/ψ con respecto a los pares de muones Drell-Yan medidos en colisiones de protones-núcleo y núcleo-núcleo con proyectiles ligeros puede ser explicada solo por la llamada supresión nuclear normal (debido a la barrida de nucleones). En contraste, el
experimento NA50
con un proyectil y blanco pesados (Pb+Pb) reveló una supresión de J/ψ esencialmente más fuerte para colisiones centrales [4–7]. Esta supresión anómala de J/ψ fue atribuida a la formación de plasma de quarks y gluones (QGP) [7], pero un escenario de comovers no puede ser excluido [8].

This experimental program was mainly motivated by the suggestion [1] to use the J/ψ as a probe of the state of matter created at the early stage of the collision.
The original picture [1] (see also [2] for a modern review) assumes that charmonia are created exclusively at the initial stage of the reaction in primary nucleon–nucleon collisions.

During the subsequent evolution of the system, the number of hidden charm mesons is reduced because of: (a) absorption of pre-resonance charmonium states by nuclear nucleons (
normal nuclear suppression
), (b) interactions of charmonia with secondary hadrons (comovers), (c) dissociation of cc̄ bound states in deconfined medium (anomalous suppression).

It was found [3] that J/ψ suppression with respect to Drell–Yan muon pairs measured in proton–nucleus and nucleus–nucleus collisions with light projectiles can be explained by the so-called normal (due to sweeping nucleons) nuclear suppression alone.
In contrast, the NA50 experiment with a heavy projectile and target (Pb+Pb) revealed essentially stronger J/ψ suppression for central collisions [4–7].
This anomalous J/ψ suppression was attributed to formation of quark–gluon plasma (QGP) [7], but a comover scenario cannot be excluded [8].

During the subsequent evolution of the system, the number of hidden charm mesons is reduced because of: (a) absorption of pre-resonance charmonium states by nuclear nucleons (normal nuclear suppression), (b) interactions of charmonia with secondary hadrons (comovers), (c) dissociation of cc̄ bound states in deconfined medium (anomalous suppression).

It was found [3] that J/ψ suppression with respect to Drell–Yan muon pairs measured in proton–nucleus and nucleus–nucleus collisions with light projectiles can be explained by the so-called normal (due to sweeping nucleons) nuclear suppression alone.

In contrast, the NA50 experiment with a heavy projectile and target (

) revealed essentially stronger J/ψ suppression for central collisions [4–7].
This anomalous J/ψ suppression was attributed to formation of quark–gluon plasma (QGP) [7], but a comover scenario cannot be excluded [8].

During the subsequent evolution of the system, the number of hidden charm mesons is reduced because of: (a) absorption of pre-resonance charmonium states by nuclear nucleons (normal nuclear suppression), (b) interactions of charmonia with secondary hadrons (comovers), (c) dissociation of cc̄ bound states in deconfined medium (anomalous suppression).

It was found [3] that J/ψ suppression with respect to Drell–Yan muon pairs measured in proton–nucleus and nucleus–nucleus collisions with light projectiles can be explained by the so-called normal (due to sweeping nucleons) nuclear suppression alone.
In contrast, the NA50 experiment with a heavy projectile and target (Pb+Pb) revealed essentially stronger J/ψ suppression for central collisions [4–7].
This anomalous J/ψ suppression was attributed to formation of quark–gluon plasma (QGP) [7], but a comover scenario cannot be excluded [8].

Production of charmonium states J/ψ and
ψ′
in nucleus–nucleus collisions has been studied at CERN SPS over the previous 15 years by the NA38 and NA50 Collaborations.
This experimental program was mainly motivated by the suggestion [1] to use the J/ψ as a probe of the state of matter created at the early stage of the collision.
The original picture [1] (see also [2] for a modern review) assumes that charmonia are created exclusively at the initial stage of the reaction in primary nucleon–nucleon collisions.

During the subsequent evolution of the system, the number of hidden charm mesons is reduced because of: (a) absorption of pre-resonance charmonium states by nuclear nucleons (normal nuclear suppression), (b) interactions of charmonia with secondary hadrons (comovers), (c) dissociation of cc̄ bound states in deconfined medium (anomalous suppression).

It was found [3] that J/ψ suppression with respect to Drell–Yan muon pairs measured in proton–nucleus and nucleus–nucleus collisions with light projectiles can be explained by the so-called normal (due to sweeping nucleons) nuclear suppression alone.
In contrast, the NA50 experiment with a heavy projectile and target (Pb+Pb) revealed essentially stronger J/ψ suppression for central collisions [4–7].
This anomalous J/ψ suppression was attributed to formation of quark–gluon plasma (QGP) [7], but a comover scenario cannot be excluded [8].
